questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding Lumbar hernia

options.label: A
options.text: Most occur through the Superior lumbar triangle

options.label: B
options.text: Inferior lumbar triangle is bounded by the 12th rib, sacrospinalis, internal oblique muscle

options.label: D
options.text: The defects can be easily closed with sutures.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Differential Diagnosis includes Lipoma Lipoma is a differential diagnosis of lumbar hernia The other differential diagnosis is an incisional hernia, a cold abscess, and a pseudo hernia.

Highyeild:

Lumbar Hernia : Most primary lumbar hernias occur through the inferior lumbar triangle of Petit bounded below by the crest of the ilium, laterally by the external oblique muscle, and medially by latissimus dorsi. Less commonly, the sac comes through the superior lumbar triangle , which is bounded by the twelfth rib above, medially by sacrospinalis, and laterally by the posterior border of the internal oblique muscle. Primary lumbar hernias are rare but may be mimicked by incisional hernias arising through flank incisions for renal operations, or through incisions for bone grafts harvested from the iliac crest. Differential diagnosis : A lumbar hernia must be distinguished from: A lipoma; An incisional hernia, such as from a renal operation A cold (tuberculous) abscess pointing to this position; A pseudo-hernia due to local muscular paralysis. Lumbar pseudo-hernia can result from any interference with the nerve supply of the affected muscles, the most common cause being an injury to the subcostal nerve during a kidney operation. Treatment: The natural history is for these hernias to increase in size and surgery is recommended. Lumbar hernias can be approached by open or laparoscopic surgery. The defects can be difficult to close with sutures and mesh is recommended.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Most occur through the Inferior lumbar triangle Option B. Superior lumbar triangle is bounded by the 12th rib, sacrospinalis, internal oblique muscle Option D. The defects can be difficult to close with sutures

questions.correct_answer: D. May spontaneously drain via the rectum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

May spontaneously drain via the rectum Left to nature, a proportion of these abscesses burst into the rectum , after which the patient almost always recovers rapidly

Highyeild:

Pelvic abscess: The pelvis is the most common site of abscess formation because the vermiform appendix is often pelvic in position and the fallopian tubes are also frequent sites of infection. A pelvic abscess can also occur as a sequel to any case of diffuse peritonitis and is common after anastomotic leakage following colorectal surgery . Clinical features: The most characteristic symptoms are pelvic pain, diarrhea, and the passage of mucus in the stools. Rectal examination reveals a bulging of the anterior rectal wall , which, when the abscess is ripe, becomes softly cystic. Investigation and management: Left to nature, a proportion of these abscesses burst into the rectum , after which the patient almost always recovers rapidly. If this does not occur, the abscess should be drained deliberately. In women, vaginal drainage through the posterior fornix is often chosen. In other cases, when the abscess is pointing into the rectum, rectal drainage is employed. If any uncertainty exists, the presence of pus should be confirmed by ultrasonography or CT scanning. Laparotomy is rarely necessary and rectal drainage of a pelvic abscess is far preferable to suprapubic drainage , which risks exposing the general peritoneal cavity to infection. It is, however, increasingly common to insert drainage tubes percutaneously, e.g., via the buttock or the vagina or rectum under CT guidance.

questions.text: A 45- year- old male with swelling of the bilateral inguinal region with expansile cough impulse is posted for bilateral hernioplasty under spinal anesthesia. To prevent SSI, pre-op shaving is done at:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Just before the operation Pre-operative skin shaving should be undertaken in the operating theatre immediately before surgery. The latest guidelines mention- No need for shaving.

Highyeild:

Preoperative Preparation A short preoperative hospital stay lowers the risk of acquiring MRSA, multidrug-resistant coagulase-negative staphylococci, and other antibiotic-resistant organisms from the hospital environment. Medical and nursing staff should always wash their hands after any patient contact . Hand gels containing at least 70% alcohol can act as a substitute for handwashing but do not destroy the spores of C. dif., which may cause pseudomembranous colitis, especially in immunocompromised patients or those whose gut fora is suppressed by antibiotic therapy. Staff with open, infected skin lesions should not enter the operating theatres . Ideally, neither should affect patients, especially if they are having a prosthesis implanted. Preoperative skin shaving should be undertaken in the operating theater immediately before surgery as the SSI rate after clean wound surgery may be doubled if shaving is performed the night before because minor skin injury enhances superficial bacterial colonization

questions.text: A 60-year-old male has a history of having undergone Exploratory laparotomy for perforation peritonitis 20 years back. The patient now presented with a hernia at the previous incision site which was diagnosed as an incisional hernia. The surgeon planned to perform the type of repair as shown in Figure C. Which type of hernia repair is represented in Figure C?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sublay Mesh placement in a pocket formed anterior to the peritoneum and posterior to the rectus abdominis . It is also called recto-rectus mesh repair.

Highyeild:

The term ‘mesh’ refers to prosthetic material, either a net or a fat sheet, that is used to strengthen a hernia repair. Positioning : The strength of a mesh repair depends on host-tissue ingrowth. Meshes should be laid in a tension-free manner on a farm, well-vascularised tissue bed with a generous overlap of the hernia zone The mesh can be placed On top of the muscle/fascia in the subcutaneous space (only) Within the defect (inlay) Immediately deep to the muscle layers in the abdominal wall (subway) Extraperitoneal Intraperitoneally. Only repair : The mesh is placed overlying the defect (opening) made by the hernia. The mesh is fixed to the fascia using sutures to close the defect. This method is relatively easy to perform. It does, however, come with some disadvantages. These disadvantages include: A lot of suturing is required to secure the mesh around and onto the fascia surface; There is an increased chance of seroma over the mesh when placed using the onlay Technique. Higher risk of recurrence due to the mechanical disadvantage of the only placement of the mesh, such that there is significant pressure against the mesh. Inlay repair : The inlay technique involves placing the mesh between the edges of the fascia where the defect made by the hernia is. Inlay placement does not close the gap, rather the mesh is fixed with sutures to the edges of the gap to bridge the defect. This technique is also relatively easy to perform. If used over larger defects, then the risk of recurrence increases as well as the formation of seromas and infection. There is also the mechanical disadvantage here where pressure against the mesh can again lead to recurrence, but more so if the technique is applied to a large gap. Sublay: Mesh placement in a pocket formed anterior to the peritoneum and posterior to the rectus abdominis. It is also called recto-rectus mesh repair. Underlay : The underlay technique involves placing the mesh on the underside of the gap or inside the fascia. Because of this technique, is also referred to as the inside-out technique for hernia repair. The sutures are circumferentially and evenly used to fix the mesh and close the gap. Because the pressure is stabilized, there is less risk of hernia recurrence . Because of its placement, too, there is less risk of seroma formation and infection . Mesh locations: a) Onlay repair, b) inlay repair, c) sublay/retromuscular repair, d) underlay repair; key: Green: mesh. Red: muscle. Blue: fascia. Grey:hernia sac/peritoneum.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Onlay repair : The mesh is placed overlying the defect (opening) made by the hernia . Hence is it onlay repair Option: B. Inlay repair : The inlay technique involves placing the mesh between the edges of the fascia where the defect made by the hernia is. Hence it is an inlay repair Option: D. Underlay : The underlay technique involves placing the mesh on the underside of the gap or inside the fascia. Hence it is underlay repair

Extraedge:

Primary perineal hernias are very rare. The majority of perineal hernias encountered are some form of incisional hernia arising after previous pelvic floor surgery or trauma. It Includes : postoperative hernia through a perineal scar, typically after excision of the rectum; median sliding perineal hernia, which is a complete prolapse of the rectum; anterolateral perineal hernia, which occurs in women and presents as a swelling of the labium majus; posterolateral perineal hernia, which passes through the levator ani to enter the ischiorectal fossa.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented to the Surgery OPD with swelling as shown in the given figure. On examination the cough impulse is positive and the contents of the swelling are reducible. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epigastric hernia Epigastric hernias, also known as fatty hernias of the linea alba, occur ventrally through a defect in the linea alba, between the umbilicus and epigastrium.

Highyeild:

Epigastric Hernia Incidence : Approximately 3% to 5% of the population has epigastric hernias. Epigastric hernias are two to three times more common in men . Like umbilical hernias, epigastric hernias are more common in individuals with a single aponeurotic decussation. Location : These hernias are located between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus and are usually within 5 to 6 cm of the umbilicus. They are multiple in up to 20% of patients, and approximately 80% are in the midline. Character : The defects are small and often produce pain out of proportion to their size because of the incarceration of preperitoneal fat. Hernia Repair : A repair usually consists of the excision of the incarcerated preperitoneal tissue and simple closure of the fascial defect , similar to that for umbilical hernias. Small defects can be repaired under local anesthesia. Uncommonly, these defects can be sizable, can contain omentum or other intraabdominal viscera, and may require mesh repairs. Epigastric hernias are better repaired anteriorly because the defect is small and fat that has herniated from within the peritoneal cavity is difficult to reduce

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Umbilical hernia : A condition in which the intestine protrudes through the abdominal muscles at the umbilicus. Many infants are born with an umbilical hernia. Umbilical hernias can also be acquired in adulthood, more often in women. A common sign of an umbilical hernia is a protruding belly button, which in infants may be most noticeable when they cry. Many hernias close on their own by age one, and most by age five. Large hernias or hernias that don't close may need surgical repair. Option: C. Spigelian hernia : Spigelian hernia occurs through a slit-like defect in the anterior abdominal wall a to the semilunar line. Option: D. Paraumbilical hernia : A hernia occurring within 3cm of the umbilicus is termed as a paraumbilical hernia. In the given case the hernia is extending beyond 3cm from the umbilicus towards the epigastrium.

Extraedge:

The most common cause of ‘recurrence’ in epigastric hernia is failure to identify a second defect at the time of original repair.

questions.text: A 40 years old female patient having congenital dislocation of the hip presented to Surgery OPD with a swelling in the groin region. On examination, the swelling is below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Which of the following is the type of hernia this patient is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Narath’s femoral hernia Narath’s femoral hernia is described as a hernia behind the femoral vessels that are due to displacement of the psoas muscle in patients with congenital hip dislocation .

Highyeild:

Femoral canal: Walls of Femoral Hernia Laterally: Femoral Vein Just medial to the vein is a small space containing fat and some lymphatic tissue (node of Cloquet) . It is this space that is exploited by a femoral hernia. Femoral hernia : Less common than inguinal hernia It is more common in women than in men Easily missed on examination Of cases 50% present as an emergency with a very high risk of strangulation. Diagnosis The hernia appears below and lateral to the pubic tubercle and lies in the upper leg rather than in the lower abdomen The hernia often rapidly becomes irreducible and loses any cough impulse owing to the tightness of the neck. It may only be 1–2 cm in size and can easily be mistaken for a lymph node . As it increases in size, it is reflected superiorly and becomes difficult to distinguish from a medial direct hernia, which arises only a few centimeters above the femoral canal . Differential Diagnosis : Inguinal hernia Lymph node Saphena varix Femoral artery aneurysm Psoas abscess Rupture of adductor longus with hematoma Investigations: USG or CT (in cases of uncertainty) Treatment: There is no alternative to surgery for a femoral hernia and it is wise to treat such cases with some urgency Open approaches Low Approach(Lockwood) Inguinal approach (Lotheissen) High approach (McEvedy) Laparoscopic Approach

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A)- Cloquet hernia - a femoral hernia perforating the aponeurosis of the pectineus and insinuating itself between this aponeurosis and the muscle, therefore lying behind the femoral vessels. Cloquet septum - the delicate fibrous membrane that closes the femoral ring at the base of the femoral canal. Option C)- Laugier's hernia : Hernia through the lacunar ligament along the anteromedial edge of the inguinal ligament. Option D)- Obturator hernia : Obturator hernia decors when there is a protrusion of intra-abdominal contents through the obturator foramen in the pelvis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old, severely obese man experienced effusion from the umbilicus for 2 months. An infected urachal remnant was diagnosed and antibiotic therapy was started. Surgery was planned after the infection subsided. Under laparoscopy, a Meckel's diverticulum incarcerated in an umbilical hernia was found. What is the most common content found in umbilical hernia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Omentum Small umbilical hernias often contain extraperitoneal fat or omentum . Larger hernias can contain small or large bowels but, even when very large, the neck of the sac is narrow compared with the volume of its contents.

Highyeild:

Umbilical Hernia The umbilical defect is present at birth but closes as the stump of the umbilical cord heals, usually within a week of birth. This process may be delayed, leading to the development of herniation in the neonatal period. The umbilical ring may also stretch and reopen in adult life In Children : Incidence : 10% of Infants with a higher incidence of premature babies Incidence in Black Infants is 8 times higher than in white Characters : Often Symptomless Becomes Conical shape on crying Rarely Strangulates Treatment: Conservative(If it persists beyond 2 years then surgery is indicated) In Adults : Incidence: Women and Overweight men Causes: Conditions that cause stretching and thinning of the midline raphe (linea alba), such as pregnancy, obesity, and liver disease with cirrhosis and ascites, predispose to the reopening of the umbilical defect Characters : One Side bulge creates a crescent-shaped appearance to the umbilicus Pain due to tissue tension Treatment: Surgical Management (Small hernias may be left alone if they are asymptomatic)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A – Preperitoneal fat is usually the content of an epigastric hernia. Option B – Umbilical hernias often contain extraperitoneal fat or omentum but omentum is the most common content found in umbilical hernias. Option D –None of the above is an option.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female farmer with a 10-year history of a voluminous mass in the anterior abdominal wall. On examination, vital signs were normal. A giant irregular mass extending from the epigastrium to the right flank measuring 32 cm × 22 cm × 8 cm was found. The overlying skin appeared normal, it was non-tender, soft, fluctuant, and irreducible. There were no bowel sounds heard over the mass but there were normoactive over the other areas. She was diagnosed with an epigastric hernia. What is the most common content in epigastric hernia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Preperitoneal fat Epigastric hernia defects are usually less than 1 cm in maximum diameter and commonly contain only extraperitoneal fat , which gradually enlarges, spreading in the subcutaneous plane to resemble the shape of a mushroom. When very large they may contain a peritoneal sac but rarely any bowel.

questions.text: A 37- year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an epigastric hernia with little diastasis recti. The patient's symptoms were a sense of discomfort, and bloat, sometimes associated with dull pain increasing with cough. She had a mild laxity of the skin in the lower part of the abdomen and the position of the navel was 16 cm from the pubic symphysis. What is the most common cause of recurrence in the case of an epigastric hernia?

questions.text: A 34- year- old female was diagnosed with an incisional hernia. The hernia width was found to be 8 cm with the presence of contamination. Which incisional hernia staging system does this patient belong to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stage II The Ventral Hernia Working Group grading scale uses patient comorbidities and wound class to predict SSO risk. Hernias could be grouped into stages (I to III) using width and wound class alone, with ordinal increments in both outcome measures. Stage II hernias are 10 to 20 cm/clean or smaller than 10 cm/ contaminated and carry an intermediate risk of SSO and recurrence.

Highyeild:

Incisional Hernia: These arise through a defect in the musculofascial layers of the abdominal wall at the site of a postoperative scar Incidence 10–50% after surgery Etiology includes patient, wound, and surgeon factors Wide variation in size Multiple defects within the same scar are very common Obstruction is common but strangulation is rare Open and laparoscopic repairs are possible Prevention: Smoking Cessation, Weight Loss for Obesity, and Good Closing Techniques

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A – Stage I hernias are smaller than 10 cm/clean and associated with low SSO and recurrence risk. Option C – Stage III hernias are either 10 cm and larger/contaminated or any hernia 20 cm or larger, and these are associated with high SSO and recurrence risk. Option D – There is no Stage IV in the incisional hernia staging system.
